hierarchy.file_name: Design--Expose issue_prioritization score breakdown in Issue Theme API + UI.docx

sections.text:
We will make Issue Theme prioritization explainable by exposing the computed `issue_prioritization` score breakdown end-to-end (API → UI). Today we compute a single rank-driving score, but the MVP needs defensible, user-readable factors. This change will add a structured breakdown that includes the total score, per-factor contributions, and the scoring configuration version used for the computation, so users can understand and audit why one theme ranks above another.

**API (Issue Theme response):** extend the Issue Theme schema to return an `issue_prioritization` object containing: `total_score`, `scoring_config_version` (or id/hash), and a `factors` map/object with numeric contributions for `frequency`, `severity`, and `arr_tier`. Each factor will also include metadata needed for explainability (e.g., the resolved input bucket/label used, and whether it was a fallback). Example shape: `factors.frequency: { contribution, value, label, is_fallback }`, similarly for severity and ARR tier. This ensures both list and detail views can render consistently without recomputing or duplicating logic client-side.

**Scoring + fallbacks:** the service that computes prioritization will annotate when defaults were applied (e.g., “unknown ARR tier → default tier”, “no explicit severity → default severity”) and surface that in the factor metadata. The total score must equal the sum of factor contributions (or be accompanied by an explicit “other/normalization” field if the model includes weights/normalization not captured by the three factors). The `scoring_config_version` will reflect the active config at calculation time to support future tuning, backfills, and debugging when scores change.

**UI (Issue Theme list + detail):** update both views to display the total score and a consistent “Score breakdown” component showing the three factor contributions with clear labels and fallback indicators. The list view should show a compact inline breakdown (e.g., Total + top-line factor pills or a popover), while the detail view shows the full table: factor name, contribution, resolved input (bucket/tier), and fallback messaging. This will make rankings defensible in reviews and enable users to quickly spot when defaults (unknown ARR tier/default severity) are influencing the ordering.
